div3.head: Poor Virginia.
div3.p:
According to the representations of those who are opposed to any resistance to Black Republicanism, Virginia is utterly helpless — nay, prostrate, and tied hand and foot, the victim of the Federal Government, to which she can never, with the slightest hope, oppose any resistance whatever.
Mr. Lincolns has but to play William of Normandy; come, see, and conquer; fix collars upon his Virginia Cedric; and these opponents of resistance are willing to play swineherds and serfs.

These Virginia partisans of the pervading and irresistible power of the Federal Government, are by their conduct and sentiments giving encouragement to Black Republicanism to persist in its obstinacy and tyranny, and adding to the complications of our national troubles.
What a thrill of pleasure must not Mr. Lincoln experience in reading the productions of the more prominent of those Unionists who propose to submit to everything rather than separate from the Federal Government, the source of power and — of patronage. How welcome must they not be to Hinton Rowan Helper, as an apparent confirmation of his book, which invited the Northern laborer to come down to the South, abolish slavery, take possession of our estates, and live like fighting cocks — while we were to become their servants.
How must they make the Abolitionists grow in their plans and preaching for coercion! Worse than all, what gloom and despondency must not emanations like these from the South bring upon those good Northern men engaged in an unequal struggle for the Constitution and rights of the South !

These patriotic and high-spirited gentlemen have reflected carefully whether their individual rights are at all impaired by Northern aggression, and conclude that they are not. --Therefore it is, that they cannot consent to extreme measures.
The elderly ladies of the Revolution might have taken even a stronger view of the question of Tea. The importation of this beverage, so far from impairing their individual comfort, contributed very much to it; and the throwing it overboard not only brought them no personal redress, but inflicted upon them serious personal discomfort.
Nevertheless, the cry of those brave old dames was, not Tea, but Liberty or Death ! A country's rights and honor may suffer while the interests of individual citizens flourish; and is the citizen in this case to let his country go to the wall?
Three-fourths of the men who fought the Revolution through, lost their individual all, while conquering the independence of their country.
They won nothing but honor.
The hero of Shrewsbury thought poorly of the commodity of which our revolutionary ancestors won so much:

q.p:
"Can honor set to a leg?
No. Or an arm?
No Or take away the grief of a wound?
No. Honor hath no skill in surgery, then?
No. What is honor?
A Word.
What is in that word, honor.
What is that honor?
Air. A trim reckoning?
Who hath it?
He that died o' Wednesday.
Doth he feel it?
No. Doth he hear it?
No. Is it insensible, then?
Yea, to the dead.
But will it not live with the living?
No. Why? Detraction will not suffer it:--therefore I'll none of it."

div3.p: The supposed Poverty and Bankruptcy of Virginia.

Those who are appealing to some of the lowest instincts of our nature, are endeavoring to excite alarm at the supposed debt of the State.
By such an appeal to fear they hope to inspire the public mind with the spirit of submission.
It is thought the suggestion that forty-five millions, "to be paid by direct taxation," will excite dismay.
But the argument turns against itself; for the State debt will not be paid by direct taxation unless we remain in league with the North.
We have already shown that a ten per cent duty on the trade of the Southern States will produce a revenue not only sufficient to defray all expenses of separate confederation, but to provide for all the debts of the individual Southern States without the necessity of direct taxation.
As to the supposed poverty of the State, as it has been produced alone by her league with the North, so it can only be relieved by separation from that contact.
Mr. Kettell, the ablest statistical writer on this side of the Atlantic, gives the following statement of the "annual load which Southern industry is required to carry" by its connection with the North:

row.cell: Profits of shipping, imports and exports
of teachers and on pulpits sent North
Profits of capital drawn from South

div3.p: Now, the saving of Virginia's portion of this huge loss for a single year would be equivalent to balancing off her entire State debt.

[As not pertinent to this article, we pass over the question as to the nature of this debt of forty millions, a large part of which is due to the Literary Fund, and therefore only a debt due to the State itself — another part of which is represented by stocks that pay regular dividends; and the payment of the whole of which in a term of years is provided for out of a fund set a part annually for the purpose.]
Blockade of Virginia Ports.

The number of persons actually employed in the manufacture of cotton, in Europe and America, is 1,350,938, which is exclusive of their families, and of all those employed in raising, transporting and selling the article and its fabrics, and in managing the banking, exchange and insurance businesses connected with the trade.
The grand aggregate of people employed in and about the article of cotton, with their families, exceeds fifty millions of souls.
Is it to be supposed that the great powers of the earth will tamely permit this colossal business to be brought suddenly to a halt by a "single frigate" at the Virginia Capes, and two or three others posted here and there along the Southern seaboard?
The thought is monstrous.
At all events, although the "single frigate" at the Virginia Capes might scare away all Great Britain, France and Germany, and prevent their coming into Norfolk for the cotton now coming down there, at the rate of ten thousand bales a month, and soon will be coming down at that rate per week, yet we hardly think that the cities of Baltimore, Richmond and Norfolk would rest namely under the plan of submitting to the impertinence.
Outside the capes is a bad roadstead in storms, and a few batteries on the headlands thereabout would easily keep out such intruders.
Nor is Fortress Monroe seriously in the way of Richmond trade; for vessels drawing thirty feet water coming into the York River, pass fifteen miles beyond the range of the guns of the fort, and arrive within thirty-eight miles of Richmond, at the terminus of the York River Railroad.
Thus, one or two batteries near the Capes, and as many upon the York River opens the way free and safe to the capital of Virginia for all the navies of Europe.

div3.head: The cotton question.
div3.p:
It has long been a problem of deepest interest to Philosopher Greeley --the Marat of the American press — how it was possible for the world to get along without the slave-grown cotton of the Southern States of this Union.
He tried Africa, India, South America, by turns, pressed with zeal the expediency of substituting flax grown by free labor for it, and set the ingenuity of all abolitionism to work to invent machinery whereby it was to be wrought as cheaply and as successfully as cotton.
This plan exploded, and then the Philosopher relied upon Providence to develop some plan to break the league with crime in the Southern States!
But a prominent Southern man comes to the relief of the Philosopher of the abolitionists.
This comforter expresses the fear (from the tenor of the language employed, we might infer it to be the wish,) that the European demand for Southern cotton will now fall off to nothing, in consequence of the subjugation of China.
The English manufacturers have been obliged to confess that as species of Asiatic or African cotton yet grown can substitute the particular qualities of cotton derived from the United States. "We need and consume nine bags of this cotton for one of all other

qualities put together," is their emphatic and reluctant language.
If India were to send us two millions of bales of the Surat cotton per annum, the desideratum would not be supplied, and our perilous problem would still be unsolved.
We should be almost as dependent on America as ever." That is the fixed and confessed fact, and the crowning feature of the case is, that the more cotton they get from the East, the more cotton the East is able to buy back manufactured into fabrics.
Indeed, the purchases of India vastly exceed her sales; for while in 1858 that country sent to Great Britain 132,000,000 pounds of raw cotton, it purchased back 223,000,000 pounds of the manufactured article, the excess being derived from the Southern United States. The great fact is, that the labor systems of China, India and Africa are incompetent to produce surpluses of raw cotton, or to compete with machinery in its manufacture.
Their tendency, therefore, is always to buy more in weight of the fabric than they sell of the raw material; and the excess comes always from the United State.--Thus, the more cotton Europe buys from Asia and Africa, the greater becomes her demand upon the United States.
Of all the regions on the globe, the Southern United States alone afford a net surplus of cotton above the weight of the cotton goods which they buy back; and so far from there being any indications of a future decline in the demand for raw cotton, it is estimated that the demand will continue to grow until it reaches 4,700,000,000 of pounds, or 10,000,000 of bales, over and above the present production.
In fact, there is an error in the calculation in regard to the future demands of cotton from the South, somewhere not very far short of ten Millions of bales.

div3.head: The Legislature.
div3.p:
The Senate, yesterday, made the bill amending the charter of the Winchester and Potomac Railroad Company the order for to-day.
Bills were reported for authorizing the issue of Treasury notes; for paying the Adjutant General for reorganizing the militia, and for increasing the pay of the commissioned officers of the Public Guard.
Bills were passed for providing efficient police regulations at the poor-houses in this State, and for allowing the Central Railroad to construct a branch to Lexington out of funds to be contributed by parties interested in the scheme.
House bill for the relief of the Banks was referred to a committee.

In the House, a message was received from the Executive, enclosing joint resolutions adopted by the Tennessee Legislature, proposing certain amendments to the Federal Constitution; also, a series of coercion resolves, adopted by the Black Republicans of the Pennsylvania Legislature, sent to the Governor by A. G. Curtin, Chief Magistrate of that Commonwealth.
The communication of Governor Letcher and the Tennessee resolutions were ordered to be printed, and referred to the Committee on State and Federal Relations.
Resolutions were offered for building a railroad in Henrico county, to connect with the York River Road, and for connecting the Baltimore and Ohio and Central Railroads by a branch, beginning in Preston and ending in Augusta county.
A bill was reported for amending the act providing additional protection to the slave property of Virginia.
The Bank Relief bill was passed.
The House laid on the table a motion to adjourn till Feb. 11 --objection being made thereto.
The proposition for a stay law was also laid on the table.

div3.head: Black Republican Espionage in Virginia.
div3.p:
The telegraph announced yesterday morning that Mr. John P. Kennedy, of the Census Department, was engaged in distributing the speeches of Messrs. Clemens and Etheridge in Virginia, evidently to bear upon the elections about to take place.
There was a mistake in the name of the gentleman.
It was Mr. Jos. C. G. Kennedy who was engaged in this work — he and his clerks, in the hours of business of the Department.

We now have a more remarkable specimen of the interest Mr. Kennedy takes in our affairs here in Virginia.
The following note was addressed by him to one of the Assistant Marshals of this State, and we suppose has been addressed to others:

div4.p: Will you have the kindness to inform me, without any delay, regarding the opinion of the people in your sub-division respecting secession, and what character of delegates you will send to the State Convention?

This is a very fair beginning of the system which we may expect to be inaugurated when the offices at the Capitol and elsewhere are filled with unscrupulous men, who are indebted to their hostility and hatred of the South for their elevation to office and for the salaries they will receive from the revenue paid chiefly by the South, Knowing that there can be little friendship among the people they have warred on for the Government they control, they will suspect them and watch them, and through spies and commissioners, after the manner of the French Republic, ascertain where there is most danger of resistance, and there plant their power to keep it in check.
The present Administration is paralytic, and the incoming is holding the palsied arm and directing the public measures.
Let the people look to their rights.

div3.head: Troops in the Federal Capital.
div3.p:
The steady progress of military preparations at Washington city is a matter for the serious consideration of the people of the South, and especially of Virginia.
The merest speculations and rumors set afloat by letter writers are made the pretext for this martial array.--An oath of a character offensive to all high-spirited men, it is said, has been framed for administration to the officers.
The whole proceeding is one of unprecedented character in this country, and one of remarkable significance.
Were the Father of His Country to be engaged in such preparations, such mysterious military movements, as have taken place, we should demand the intent and purpose of them.

div3.head: Working Men's meeting.
div3.p:
The loyalty manifested at the Working Men's Meeting, in this city, to the Union and the South, is eminently illustrative of the generous and self-sacrificing nature of the Virginia character.
Virginia did not come into the Union from selfish considerations, and her relative importance has steadily declined ever since; but there has been no diminution in the intensity of her patriotism.
It is in the same magnanimous and disinterested spirit that the working men disregard the inevitable aggrandizement of our city as the great manufacturing city of the South, which would follow disunion.
At the same time, they stand by Virginia in an unbroken phalanx, and, unless her just demands are secured, will sustain her in any course which the emergency may demand.

div3.head: Burnt.
div3.p:
--The burning vessel passed by the ship Scargo, lat. 34, long.
69, is supposed to be the brig Cura, commanded by Capt. P. F. Peascod of Raleigh, N. C. His vessel is six weeks over due. Capt. P. went to California soon after the settlement of that country, and amassed a fortune, which he converted into gold, expecting to leave for Virginia in a day or two, when the memorable fire which occurred 6th May communicated with the hotel where his treasure was deposited, (while he was settling with his commission merchant,) and he lost everything but the clothes he had on. He again shipped as mate of a Clipper bound for Calcutta, and ever since has been in the command of vessels in the Rio and Mediterranean trade.

div3.opener:
To Messrs. William F. G. Garnett, Nathaniel F. Bowe, Jno W. Atkinson, and Jno. A. Hutcheson:
Gentlemen:
div3.p:
Your letter informing me "that at a meeting this day held, of the friends of those gentlemen who have been most prominently presented, to represent the State's-Rights party of the county of Henrico in the Virginia Convention, my name was unanimously agreed upon as the candidate," has this moment been received.
In reply, I have only to say, that with unaffected diffidence in my qualifications for the post, which you have assigned me, I shall endeavor to hold up the State's-Rights banner as best I can in the short canvass before me, and if it shall be the pleasure of my fellow-citizens of the county to elect me, I shall serve them to the very best of my ability.

div3.head: To the Public.
div3.p:
--I am informed it is reported on the street that I have withdrawn as a candidate for the State Convention. This is not so. I shall maintain the position assigned me by my friends, and hope no more such idle reports will be put in circulation.
I am announced by my friends as a Douglas candidate, and as such I shall continue a candidate until the close of the polls on the day of election.

Respectfully, J. H. Gilmer.

[Extract from the Report of Judges at Fair of Va. Mechanics' Institute, 1860.]

No. 1.
The Wheeler & Wilson Machine makes what is popularly called the lock stitch, and in view of the economy of thread required for said stitch, its elasticity, strength and beauty of appearance, the committee prefer it for the practical purposes of sewing.

"We find in this Machine simplicity — all parts being particularly adapted to each other, and to the office which they perform, resulting in a freedom from derangement and need for repairs, with an ease of adjustment not attained in the more complicated contrivances.
In our examination we find in Wheeler & Wilson's Machines these advantages over all others: 1st.
Its bearing surfaces and parts having a reciprocating motion are very light, and the more rapid motions are rotary and continuous, thus economizing both time and power. 2d. One tension, which is arranged with peculiar simplicity and perfection, controls both threads.
3d.
The simple manner of controlling the loop of the needle and thread, dispenses with the use of take-up, so objectionable in other machine."

I Hereby Forewarn all persons from crediting my son, John Mesco, on my account, as I will not be responsible for any of his transactions.

div3.head: Old Dominion Institute--Corner of Franklin and 5th streets.--
div3.p: The second half of the session of this School, for 1860-'61, will commence on the 15th of February and end the 30th of June next ensuing.

The Rev. Francis J. Boggs has been added to the Board of Instruction, and will, with his family, reside in the Institute buildings.
The Musical Department will continue under Mr. Chase's superintendence, who will be aided by competent assistants.
A gentleman has been employed to take charge of the classes in Algebra, and others will be to teach other specific studies; and another female teacher will be employed.
The Lectures on Biblical Literature, by Rev. Jas. A. Duncan, will be continued, as also the Friday Afternoon Literary Lectures.
The Preparatory Department, for very small girls, will receive the special care of the Principal of the School.
The Boarding Department will be liberally and carefully conducted, and every comfort and facility will be afforded to young ladies boarding in the family.
No labor or expense will be spared to make the School equal to any in the land for the education of females.
For further information, address
J. E. Shumate, Principal.

Richmond, January, 1861.

div3.head: To the Public.
div3.p:
--In consequence of having received an appointment to the Presidency of "Quincy Academy," at Quincy, Florida, the Rev. R. F. Stubbs will resign his post in the Union Female Collegiate Institute, on the 1st of February next.
The Chair thus vacated will be filled by the appointment of Mr. Leonidas Points, A. B., a graduate of the University of Virginia.

It being reported that this institute will close on the 1st of February, I take this occasion to correct this mistake.
I have no intention of that kind whatever, and still solicit a share of the patronage of the citizens of Richmond and vicinity.
W. J Points, M. D.,

Principal.

div3.head:
Exchange Hotel and Ballard House.
Richmond, January 14th, 1861.
div3.p:
The proprietors of this well-known and popular establishment beg leave to return their heartfelt thanks to their friends and the public generally, for the liberal patronage they have at all times been favored with; and it affords them pleasure to announce that the recent changes, removals, and a thorough renovating of the entire establishment, makes it one of the most pleasant and comfortable Hotels (for permanent boarders, as well as transient company,) that can be enjoyed any where in the country.
It is due to the liberality of the Stockholders of the Exchange to say that everything has been done which could add to its value and increase the comfort and convenience of its guests.

Among the important changes and improvements in the Ballard House, they have added a well arranged and convenient Restaurant, which is now open for the patronage of the public.
In arranging this part of their business, a handsome room has been provided for the ladies of the Hotel, with a private entrance from the parlor floor of the Ballard House.
In view of the large expenditures, and renewed energy, and strict attention on their part, they hope to merit a continuance of that patronage so long enjoyed by them.

John P. & Thos. E. Ballard.

div3.p: --Joseph P. Kave nagh has, by his deed of the 19th instant (which is of record in the Clerk's Office of the Hustings Court of the City of Richmond,) conveyed to me in trust, for the benefit of his creditors, all of his stock of Groceries, consisting of the usual variety, together with his Fixtures and Furniture, upon the premises No. 172, on the north side of Broad street, in the said city; also, a Horse and Wagon, and his Books, Accounts, and choses in action of every description.
There is a clause in the deed, giving forty days to the creditors of the second class to execute the same, thereby getting the benefit of it, and releasing the grantor from further liability.
Mr. Geo. B. Clark has authority, for the present, to collect any debts due to the Trustee.

Wm. F. Watson, Trustee.

The hands have been for some years (under my control and superintendence,) in the employ of Messrs. Scott & Adams, extensive Railroad Contractors, who have suspended business for the present.

Saunders & Co., we will continue the business at the old stand lately occupied by them, under the firm and style of Saunders & Loving, where will always be found a well-selected stock of Groceries, Liquors, &c., which will be sold at the lowest prices for cash, or to punctual customers on time, and to which we invite the attention of the patrons of the late concern of Saunders & Co., and the public generally — hoping, by strict attention to business, to give satisfaction to all who may favor us with a call.
John F. Saunders,
Edwin B. Loving.

In retiring from the firm of J. F. Saunders& Co., I return my thanks to my friends for the favors bestowed on me, and take great pleasure in recommending to them, and the public generally, my successors as gentlemen worthy of their patronage.
I would also request all persons having claims against the late concern of J. F. Saunders & Co., to present them for payment, and those indebted will make payment to me, or to my son, J. F. Saunders, as early as possible.
David J. Saunders

Richmond, Jan. 21, 1861.
ja 26--d15t&cwn

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The Co-partnership heretofore existing between the undersigned is this day dissolved by mutual consent.
The affairs of the concern will be settled by Wm. B. Isaacs, who is authorized to use the name of the firm for that purpose.
Joseph Brummel,
Wm. B. Isaacs,
Wm. F. Taylor.
Richmond, 1st January, 1861.

The undersigned will continue the Exchange and Banking business of the late firm of Isaacs & Taylor.
It will be conducted under the style and firm of Wm.B. Isaacs & Co., B. H. Smith, Jr., having an interest therein.
1st January, 1861. Wm. B. Isaacs.

In withdrawing from the Exchange andBanking business, we feel it due to our successor to say that, from a long personal acquaintance and business connection with him, we have every confidence in his means, ability, integrity and prudence in the management of his affairs, and do most cordially recommend him to our friends and the public as every way worthy of their confidence and patronage.
Joseph Brummel,

Wm. F. Taylor.
ja 1--1m

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p:
--The firm of Britton & Powell is this day dissolved by mutual consent.
All persons having claims against the firm will present them to James H. Britton for settlement: and those indebted to the firm will please make immediate payment to Thos. Powell, who alone is authorized to receive money due the firm.
James H. Britton,
Thomas Powell.

The undersigned will continue the Dry Goods business, and feeling truly thankful for the liberal patronage heretofore bestowed, begs a continuance of the same.
I shall endeavor to keep on hand an assortment of Goods which cannot be surpassed in quality, and as I am determined to sell exclusively for cash, will be satisfied with a very small advance above cost.
All that I ask is a call before purchasing elsewhere.

James H. Britton.
ja 24--d1w &cw1t

div3.head: Co-Partnership.
div3.p:
--I have this day associated with me in the Commission business, Mr. Rudolph King, who has for some years been in my employment.
The business will here after be conducted under the style of L. Waller & Co. Returning my thanks for the very liberal patronage hereto fore bestowed on me, I respectfully solicit a continuance of the same for the new concern.
L. Waller.
[ja 1--d&cw1m]

The firm of Jones & Co. having dissolved, I shall continue to carry on business at the same place, No. 8 Main street, where will always be found a large stock of fine imported and domestic Liquors, provisions and Groceries, of all kinds, which will be sold on reasonable terms, to which I invite the attention of the trade generally.
Thomas Jones.

January 1st, 1861.
ja 1--1m

The stock embraces the usual variety of goods in the Drug line.
The friends and patrons of the late concern are respectfully solicited to continue their favors.
A. L. Shepherd

Richmond, Jan. 1st, 1861.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 19, Number 27, page 3.

div3.head:
From South Carolina.
Tre Virginia resolutions.
div3.p:
The resolution adopted by South Carolina to reply to the Virginia resolutions have been published.
The proceedings in the South Carolina Legislature connected with their reception are interesting.
In the House, the following message was received from Gov. Pickens:
Gentlemen His Excellency, the Governor of Virginia, has transmitted to me the enclosed resolutions, passed by the Legislature of that illustrious Common wealth.

It will be seen that their object is to induce the Legislature of South Carolina to send on Commissioners to meet Commissioners from Virginia, and also from all the States that think proper to send similar Commissioners, on the 4th of February next, in Washington city to "consider, and, if practicable, to agree upon some suitable adjustment" of the great issues that have been made in the Confederacy.

We are disposed to treat with the most profound consideration every proposition that may emanate from the State of Virginia, and to yield to her almost everything, except what may involve vital principles.
More than a year ago the State of South Carolina, actually by a most sincere desire to do everything to her power to avert the dangers that it was manifest then threatened the Federal Union, Commissioner to Virginia, and made an urgent appeal to her to step forward and devise some plan upon which the States immediately concerned might act together, and save their peace and their rights, and yet preserve the common Constitution as a blessing for all the States.
It was then thought unnecessary, on the part of Virginia, to take any steps to act in concert with South Carolina.
If our States had acted at that period, perhaps something might have been done to secure new guarantees by which our peace and our charted rights might have been protected in a common Union.
As far as the Northern States are concerned, they have, many of men often violated their obligations as States under the Federal compact; and the compromises that have been made being the two great sections of the Con- federacy have been wantonly set aside.
We have appealed in vain to their plighted both and to the integrity of the covenant.--We have been traduced and denounced through their pulpits, their press, their orators, and their statesmen, as unworthy of equality both them as States, and even as their inferiors in a social point of view.
Their people have united in over whelming majorities at the recent elections, upon issues which openly involve our peace and existence, to put into power a party who entertain the deepest and most malignant hostility to our institutions and to our people.
This is the great overt act of the people at the ballot-box, from which there no appeal to any higher tribunal, under our system of government.
They have greed to place at the head of the army and navy a President, not for the protection of the rights and the peace of our people under a common inheritance, fixed and transmitted to express charters from the very origin of the government, but with open and avowed principles of deep and settled hostility, and with pledges made by him, at the head of a powerful party, for the final extermination of institutions essential to our power as a people and to the peace of our society.
We have been forced to resume our original powers of government and to assert our separate sovereignty as a State, in order to seek that protection which we were compelled to believe would not be given to us and to our people under the power of such a party and such a Chief Magistrate.

Under these circumstances, however much I might be disposed to yield the most profound respect to the State of Virginia, and to any suggestion from her, yet it is difficult to perceive upon what grounds this State could agree to send Commissioners to Washington to meet Commissioners from the Northern States as well as from the Southern States.-- It might only result in deeper and wider difficulty and confusion.
I refer the whole matter with great deference, to your wisdom and decision, hoping in any event that the kindest and most respectful reply may be made to Virginia.

Perhaps it is not improper to state that this State has agreed, through her Convention, to meet delegates from other seceding States, at Montgomery on the fourth of February, and our Convention has actually appointed delegator to attend this meeting from these States.
The object of this Convention of States at Montgomery, will be to form immediately a common Government for the States that have seceded, and by efficient organization to secure their permanent independence beyond the reach of any contingency.
It would obviously be impolitic for this State to send delegates to a meeting at Washington, appointed for the same day, to meet the States of the North with a view to preserve or to reconstruct the Federal Union with them, when we have agreed first to meet our sister seceding States, to whom we owe our deepest obligations, and feel bound by every tie to make no compromises with any other powers until we have first formed with them a separate and independent Union. F. W. Pickens.
The resolutions of the General Assembly of Virginia were then read.
Mr. Aldrich offered the following resolutions.

Resolved, That South Carolina receives with pleasure the expressions of kindly feeling extend- ed to her by the State of Virginia, as contained in the resolutions of the General Assembly, appointing the Hon. Judge John Robertson a Commissioner to the State of South Carolina.

Resolved, That under the policy adopted by South Carolina, inasmuch as the State of South Carolina has dissolved her connection with the Government of the United States and seceded from the late union known as the United States, and inasmuch as this State has invited the seceding States to meet her in Convention at Montgomery, on the 4th day of February next, which invitation has been accepted by the States seceding, the invitation of Virginia to appoint Commissioners to assemble in Washington for the purposes indicated in the first resolution of the General Assembly of Virginia, communicated by the Hon. John Robertson to this State is respectfully declined.
After some debate--
Mr. Tracy offered the following resolutions as an amendment to those of Mr. Aldrich:

Resolved, That this Legislature receives, with the most respect, the proposition from the illustrious common wealth of Virginia, contained in the preamble and resolutions adopted by the General Assembly of that State on the 19th of January, 1861, and forwarded to this Legislature.

Resolved, That the General Assembly of this State has neither the power nor the will to re-unite this State with the Union known as the United States; and therefore, respectfully declines to entertain the proposition of Virginia.
After further debate--
Mr. Rhett offered the following resolutions as a substitute for the resolutions of Mr. Aldrich:

Resolved, That the State of South Carolina, in severing the ties which bound her to the Federal Union did not act hastily or without the fullest and most thorough deliberation, and that her session from the United States was final and irreducible, and that she cannot, therefore, with honor, dignify or good policy, send Commissioners as requested; and that South Carolina, therefore, with all deference to the illustrious Commonwealth of Virginia, declines her proposition.
Resolved. That the sympathy of Virginia with South Carolina, as expressed in the resolutions transmitted, is received with pleasure by this State.

After some further debate, a series of resolutions were received from the Senate and adopted.
They are those already published.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
Military Affairs in Fredericksburg — the Canvass,&c.
div3.p:
We are getting in the spirit of war, here.--The ranks of our battalion of volunteers are filled with reliable members, divided into two companies, the whole under command of Major Wm. S. Barton.
The Fredericksburg company of Artillery, recently organized, and now numbering nearly 70 men, has adopted its constitution and uniform.
The latter is made out of the grey kersey, manufactured at the woolen mill in this place — an article of goods very popular in this section.

The canvass is an exciting one for the Convention.
Our candidates are Messrs. J. L. Marye, Sr., and Wm. S. Barton; and, so far, the race seems to be "neck and neck," Both are high-toned, intelligent gentlemen, and the friends of each seem to be equally sanguine of success.

The secession feeling is decidedly on the increase in this vicinity.
At the call of gentlemen of all parties, Chas. T. Goolrick, Esq., a lawyer of fine abilities, delivered a lengthy and interesting speech here on Friday night last.
In exhibiting the policy of Virginia to secede immediately from the Union, his address was very effective, discussing, as it did, the affairs of the present crisis in a most eloquent and argumentative manner.
Your paper has a very large circulation here, and is always welcome.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
increase of population in Petersburg.
div3.p:
Pocahontas is doing bravely — earning a name that can't be beat in this State.
A colored woman named Nutty, last night, gave birth to a fine healthy child, to the great satisfaction of her delighted spouse, and to his great dissatisfaction, gave birth to two more this morning.
Three at one pop is pretty good, and I don't think the State can beat it.
Sixty-four free negroes reached Portsmouth, Va., Tuesday, from Halifax county, N. C., on their way to Ohio.

div3.head:
From Washington.
[special correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p:
South Carolina's response to Judge Robertson, though it offend the Abolition tag-rag party in Virginia, will satisfy the world that that gallant and sincere State is in very earnest.
Any other response would have proved that succession was a pitiful farce, intended only for party effect.
South Carolina's independence must be acknowledged now, or blood will flow at Sumter.
I shudder to think how many noble young gentlemen must be sacrificed at the hands of a few hireling soldiers, but I remember how priceless is the boon of liberty — of deliverance from Abolition tyranny.

"Lincoln has written conciliatory letters here." So says the telegraph this morning.--Now, I know this to be a Republican lie, to influence the Virginia election.
The Herald's Springfield correspondent, in yesterday's paper, says emphatically that there is to be no compromise.
I hope Robert E. Scott, Esq., will not fail, at the earliest moment, to apprise the people of Virginia of the exact position of the Republicans, as ascertained by himself during frequent conferences with their leaders while he was in this city a few days ago. I have it, from the best authority, that John Sherman says the object of his party is to soothe the Border States into the Abolition Union, and then to whip the Gulf States in.

Mr. Pryor's speech yesterday attracted an immense audience, and is highly praised both for its matter and manner of delivery by those who heard it. The voluntary compliments bestowed upon it by a gentleman on the street, who did not even know Mr. Pryor; and the fact, as stated to me by a Tennessee member, that it elicited the heartiest applause from the galleries given during the session to any speech, prove it to have been no ordinary effort.
But, for philosophic depth and vigor of thought, the best speech, without exception, delivered hitherto in either house, is, in my opinion, that of M. R. H. Garnett, Esq. I read it in full last night, for the first time. --It ought to be in the hands of every sensible man in Virginia.

I have lately received a letter from a lady living in San Antonio, Texas.
Secession has carried the day even among the motley population of that city.
She says:

q.p:
"I have just finished two songs, and am having them set to music, to be song at a concert got up by the ladies of this place for the purpose of procuring arms and ammunition to send to the frontier.
One is a mere squib, called 'Cotton Doodle.' It is not 'my style, ' and I do not put my signature to it. But to 'The Lone Star,' I do. Both are denounced as treasonable by the Union men. I will send them to you when I get the music, in order that you may see how much treason can emanate from one little lady."

Another letter from the University of Virginia says that everybody there is for straight-out secession, and that Prof. Holcombe will be elected to the Convention.
The writer adds: "The eulogies on the Union of the submissionists are but empty praises lavished on a corpse.
I am emphatically opposed to any disgraceful compromise, or patched up peace.
I think the border States have disgraced themselves already.
Compromises should come from the North, for they are the aggressors. As much as I revere the memory of the revolutionary heroes, and though I know civil war is to be deprecated on many accounts, yet, rather than see Virginia a suitor for favors at the hands of the North, I would prefer to see blood flow like the cataract of Niagara, and Chaos reign supreme over this once happy and prosperous country." God bless the boy ! he talks like a book; yea, like an entire library of the most plucky and pugnacious volumes.
His is the spirit which should animate young Virginia.

And the sweet good man, Scott, and the lovely truthful man, Buchanan, are having large cannon, pointing inland, mounted at Fortress Monroe.
Aha ! you are there, are you, old moles?
Suppose Marse Abe won't give up Monroe, but constantly reinforce it — as he can easily do. " Twill take 20,000 men and a six months seige to regain it. A delicious egg, this, for Virginia to breakfast on next spring.
Hadn't we all better back square down, squat in the dust, and eat it, and beg Lincoln's pardon, and glorify the Union ?--Hooray for the cannon-Union ! Hoozay for Virginia's blood, bayonets and gunpowder independence ! Zoohay for our mild, merciful Mandingo Master, Abraham Lincoln !

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
political Speaking — candidates for the Convention.
div3.p:
The County Court was in session to-day, but adjourned to give place to political speeches from Ex-Gov. Fayette McMullen, candidate for Congress in the Thirteenth Congressional District, and Col. A. M. Davis and Col. Wm. C. Parks, candidates for a seat in the Virginia Convention, to assemble in Richmond on the 13th of February next.
These gentlemen declared their wish to remain in the Union, if they could do so with honor to themselves.
Col. Davis said he would offer the Crittenden Resolutions as the ultimatum of the South.
Robt. P. Baker, the new Sheriff of Grayson, took the oath of office to-day.

The village of Independence, and the entire county of Grayson, is rapidly improving.
I think capital could be profitably invested here.
The winter has been unusually severe in the mountains; yet we are all doing well — nothing like cold winters to brace the body and the mind.

div3.head:
Later from Europe.
arrival of the Bohemian.
div3.p: --The steamship Bohemian, from Liverpool on the 17th, with dates to the 18th via Londonderry, has arrived.
The Anglo-Saxon and Fulton had arrived out.
It is reported in Paris that a decree will soon be issued, declaring that if Piedmont makes war on Austria, she need not expect French assistance.
Great military preparations were progressing in France.
The Spanish Government had ordered strict neutrality on the part of its vessels at Gaeta.
Naples.--The bombardment of Gaeta is to be resumed on Monday.

The Times deprecates the secession movement in America.
It says, should a Southern Confederation become the real United States, as far as present and prospective territory is concerned, it is difficult to say whether the connection between New York and New England on the one hand, and Illinois and New England on the other, could long survive a total separation from the South.
Commercial.

Liverpool, Jan. 17.--Cotton-- Sales for the week of 132,000 bales; speculators taking 21,000 and exporters 15,000 bales-- fair and middling qualities advanced ½@¼ inferior advanced ½ and scarce: Orleans Fair 8d.; Middling 7½ Uplands Fair 7½ Middling 7½.
Stock in port 520,000 bales, including 365,000 American.

Friday--Market closed active and buoyant.--Breadstuffs quiet and steady.
Wheat opened easier, but unchanged.
Provisions dull.
Consols 91½.

div3.head: Congressional.
div3.p:
--House.--Mr. Cobb, of Ala., presented the Ordinance of Secession of that State and withdrew, expressing his regret at the necessity of leaving.
He exhorted the Republicans to do something to restore peace to the distracted country.
Mr. Reynolds, of N. Y., from the Committee of Five, reported a bill authorizing the President to call out the militia in certain cases.
Mr. Branch, of N. C., presented a counter report.

Mr. Cochrane, of N. Y., presented another report against secession, but also against coercion.
He also reported a bill, in effect that when the revenue laws are obstructed in any State, the President may issue a proclamation suspending them, to be restored if the State returns to the Union.
The report was recommitted.
The Philadelphia Working Men's petition was presented.

The resolutions of the Ohio.
Democratic Convention were presented and referred to a select committee of five.

A communication was received from the President, announcing the fact that he had signed the Kansas bill.
Subsequently, Martin F. Conway, the member from that Territory, was sworn and took his seat.
The report of the Committee of Thirty-Three was resumed.

Mr. Conklin denounced the secessionists as apostates and rebels.
He made a semi-abolition speech.
He would, however, do something for the border States, but would not vote to re-establish the Missouri Compromise.
Mr. Stevenson said if Mr. Conklin was a fair exponent of the Republican party, there was no chance for a compromise; but he still hoped border State Commissioners would be able to do something.
Mr. Crittenden's proposition was offered as an equitable adjustment.
Mr. Howard, of Ohio, made a conciliatory speech in favor of compromise.

Mr. Morris, of Pa., wished to banish the agitating question of slavery from Congress.-- He favored the majority report of the Committee of Thirty-Three.
If he could not get this, he would take the Border State resolutions, or submit the whole matter to the people.
Adjourned.
Senate.--The Philadelphia Working Men's memorial was presented by Mr. Bigler.

Messrs. Cameron and Bigler endorsed it in a few brief remarks.
The former said he was willing to make concessions for the sake of pence.

Mr. Mason objected to the term concession.
The South wanted no concession.
She only wanted her rights.
Mr. Trumbull favored the enforcement of the laws.
The Pacific Railway bill was passed--37 to 14.

The Pike's Peak Territory bill was discussed and amended.
No vote taken.

div3.head: The Revenue law.
div3.p:
--Hon. Jno. Cochrane, of New York, from the Select Committee of Five, introduced a bill proposing that vessels from foreign ports, bound to a port within the scope of the provisions of said bill, shall, with its foreign cargo, be liable to seizure and condemnation, and in the same view, of applying its restrictions only to foreign commerce on which revenue is by law collected.
All vessels lawfully engaged in the coastwise trade are exempted from its operations, which are purely remedial and defensive.
It further provides, if practicable, to collect the revenue.
The President shall, by proclamation, specify the port in which the obstruction exists.

div3.head: Adjournment of the Georgia Convention.
div3.p: --The Convention to-day refused to reconsider the vote on the Revenue ordinance adopted yesterday.
A resolution was introduced giving the Government certain powers to make reprisals.-- Tabled.
An address to the citizens of the South and the world, setting forth the causes of Georgia's secession, was adopted.
An ordinance declaring it the fixed policy of the State to guarantee security to all seceded States, was adopted.
The Convention then adjourned, to meet at Savannah on the call of its President.

div3.head: Missouri Legislature.
div3.p:
--A joint resolution has passed the Senate, appointing Commissioners to Washington on the 4th prox.
The same resolution was introduced in the House and laid on the table.
The House adopted a resolution, taking strong ground against New York and Ohio adding the General Government to coerce the seceding States.

div3.head: From North Carolina.
div3.p:
--The House has concurred in the Senate's amendments to the Convention bill, and it has finally passed.
It puts the question of "Convention or no Convention." The election is to take place on the 28th February, and the delegates to the Convention are restricted in their action in that body to Federal affairs.

div3.head: The National Convention.
div3.p: --Mr. Corwin, of Ohio, to-day received the following dispatch from the Governor of Rhode Island :

p.q: "The Legislature of Rhode Island to-day appointed Commissioners to the Washington Convention. God give success to the movement."

div3.head: From Havana.
div3.p:
--The De Soto, from Havana on the 27th, has arrived.
Sugars dull.
The new crop was coming in. Money was tight.
Exchange nominal.
The Spanish Bank had authorized the issue of $2,000,000 more of bonds.

div3.head: Secession meeting.
div3.p:
--There was a great secession meeting at the Theatre last night.
Among the speakers were many who formerly advocated compromise.
Wilmington is almost a unit for secession.

div3.head: Specie from Texas.
div3.p: --The Arizona, from Brazos, is coming up with $2,043,000 in specie.

div4.p:
--Flour dull at $5.25@$5.37--no sales.
Wheat buoyant — Red $1.30@ $1.35;White $1.45@$1.65. Corn firmer — Yellow 61--65;White 70@73 Provisions steady — Mess Pork $18 ½. Coffee 11 ½@12 ½.
Whiskey steady at 18@18 ½.

--Cotton steady; sales of 6,700 bales. Flour quiet at yesterday's quotations.
Wheat easier: red $1.32; white $1.55@1.60.
Corn firm: mixed 69@70.
Provisions dull and unchanged: Lard 10 ½@10 ½.
Whiskey 18 ½.
Sugar heavy: N. O. 4 ½ @6 ½.
Coffee steady at 11 ½@13 ½.--Turpentine firm at 36.
Rosin dull.
Rice steady at 3 ½@4 ½.
Stocks opened lower, but closed firmer under the European news: N. Y. Centrals 80 ½; Va. 6's 75 ½; Mo. 6's 68 ½.

Sales in New YorkJanuary 29, of $1,000 Va. 6's at 75 ½; $19,000 Tenn.
6's at 74 ½, and $5,000 N. C. 6's at 77

div2.head:
The State Convention.
[for other "State Convention" Notices, sec 2d pages.]

div3.head: James Lyons, Esq., a candidate for the Convention for Henrico County.
div3.p:
--Be pleased to announce that James Lyons, Esq., will be voted for to represent Henrico in the Convention soon to assemble in Virginia.
Mr. Lyons' exalted character and commanding abilities so eminently fit him for the position, that nothing further need be said to ensure him a large vote.
ja 22--10t

div3.head: To J. M. Estes, W. M. Caldwell, J. B. Ferguson, and others.
div3.p:
--in compliance with your invitation, and that of many other citizens, I declare myself a candidate to represent the city in the State Convention.
Respectfully,
John Robertson.

City papers will please copy.
ja 2d--dtde*

div3.head: For the Convention.
div3.p: --Robt. F. Morris will be voted for as one of the Delegates to the State Convention, from this city, by many voters, who appreciate his peculiar fitness for the position.
ja 18--tde*
in Compliance with the wishes of many friends, I announce myself as a candidate for the State Convention, to be held on the 13th of the ensuing month.

Robert F. Morriss.
ja 29--6t*

div3.head: Henrico County.
div3.p: --Wms. C. Wickham is a candidate to represent Henrico County in the Convention.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--I will give $20 reward for the return of my Negro man "Washington," who left my house, in the lower part of Henrico county, on the morning of the 17th inst., without leave or provocation.
Washington is about five feet 8 or 9 inches high, very black, about twenty years old, and has very white teeth, and smiles very pleasantly when spoken to. He will probably have a forged pass in his possession, as he can read and write.

I will give the above reward for his return to me at my house, or if he is secured in jail so that I can get him. L. S. Courteny.
[je 26--lw*]
